description: From Middle English sloor (“thin or fluid mud”). Cognate with Middle Low German sluren (“to trail in mud”). Also related to dialectal Norwegian sløra (“to be careless, to scamp, dawdle”), Danish sløre (“to wobble, be loose”) (especially for wheels); compare Old Norse slóðra (“to drag oneself along”).

entries.meaning: A mark, stain, or smear; (by extension) a slight occasion of reproach.
An act of running one's words together; poor verbal articulation.
A disparaging insult or slight, particularly one used to denigrate a specific group.
(music) A set of notes that are played legato, without separate articulation.
(music) The symbol indicating a legato passage, written as an arc over the slurred notes (not to be confused with a tie).
In knitting machines, a device for depressing the sinkers successively by passing over them.

verbs.description: slur (third-person singular simple present slurs, present participle slurring, simple past and past participle slurred)

entries.meaning: To run together; to articulate poorly.
examples: to slur syllables;  He slurs his speech when he is drunk.

entries.meaning: (music) To play legato or without separate articulation; to connect (notes) smoothly.
examples: Notes , the stems of which are joined together by cross lines, as in united quavers , semiquavers , & c . or notes over the heads of which a curve is drawn, to signify that they are to be slurred

entries.meaning: To soil; to sully; to contaminate; to disgrace.
To cover over; to disguise; to conceal; to pass over lightly or with little notice.
To cheat, as by sliding a die; to trick.
(printing, dated) To blur or double, as an impression from type; to mackle.
